author: fvlkrum
content:
Hey everyone, bit of help and clarity in regards to a Q I have for invoking 'Transfer Fees' on Ethereum 
Is it possible to have an outcome that allows for a use case, where User1 transfers Tokens to User2, User1 pays a fee that's a variable fee set by Admin? 

For example, if User1 transfers 100 Tokens to User2, User 1 might pay in 50 Tokens today as a transfer fee, but tomorrow it may cost 30. And the 50 or 30 is somehow set by Admin

author: schone_wizard
content: question about ERC-721

author: schone_wizard
content: how come the tokens minted, don't require a hash in addition to the URI? what prevents someone from changing the underlying later on.

author: schone_wizard
content: say you buy an NFT of a text file containing some great poetry, but later the seller empties the text file after you bought the NFT token

author: treyzania
content: if there's no commitment to the "body", then nothing

author: treyzania
content: presumably if you buy an nft of that you should make sure it has that

author: schone_wizard
content: what do you mean by commitment?

author: schone_wizard
content: is this part of the ERC-721 standard i missed

author: treyzania
content: like, a hash commitment

author: treyzania
content: you can associate a lot of kinds of data with an nft, erc721 only specifies the basic mechanisms, what gets associated with it and what behaviors it has is dependent on the issuing contract (and any ux used to interact with it)

author: eugeen001
content: ERC-721 standard is an agreement

author: eugeen001
content: it has nothing to do if someone edits few lines of code

author: schone_wizard
content: are you guys saying that nothing precludes me from creating my own ERC-721 that has more fields than just tokenURI to satisfy whatever requirements i want to add?

author: schone_wizard
content: to the "agreement"

author: eugeen001
content: yes

author: eugeen001
content: its an agreement, and it's your decision to be compliant with ERC721 standard or not

author: schone_wizard
content: okay, so let me modify my question by just a bit...

author: schone_wizard
content: in the case of something like opensea... what exactly is the agreement or the assurance in regards to the underlying given that its just a tokenURI thats given in the contract?

author: jgm
content: `tokenURI` is an optional extension to ERC-721 itself.  You can add whatever metadata you like to the data retrieved from `tokenURI`, and you can set up whatever additional fields and rules for the token you desire.

author: jgm
content: Standards are minimal.  There could be a function in an ERC-721 compliant token contract that swapped the data pointed to by a given token.  Up to you to confirm that this isn't the case if you're going to spend money on the token.

author: schone_wizard
content: is there such guarantee in opensea's current implementation that i'm missing or not understanding?

author: schone_wizard
content: i understand what ERC-721 is and isn't offering (thank you for your feedback on that) and I also understand what responsibilities someone who is going to dump some money has.  what I dont understand is the current lifecycle stage of this craze.  what exactly is being guaranteed

author: jgm
content: The only guarantees can come from the individual contract developers (and these should not, of course, be trusted)

author: schone_wizard
content: got ya

author: schone_wizard
content: thank you all for your feedback, i really appreciate it

author: treyzania
content: Have you read the spec itself?

author: treyzania
content: That's pretty detailed

author: schone_wizard
content: yes I have, and i've noticed that the tokenID can theoretically be used as a hash given that its' a uint256 and it should be treated as a 'black box' from what the standard said

author: schone_wizard
content: but what I don't see is this kind of treatment in the wild... a la opensea

author: treyzania
content: yeah it's really loosely enforced

author: treyzania
content: which is pretty bad imo

author: schone_wizard
content: couldn't agree more. this feels like a ticking time bomb

author: schone_wizard
content: when the 'product' is entirely a belief based one, like proving a membership or having belong to a club, I can understand it.  when the 'product' is a consumable like art work, or a song or what not, i don't really understand it

author: javier.e.glz
content: Opensea is actually not even adding a tokenMetadata attribute on their default nft minting contract, so you are literally just buying an entry managed by them

author: Deleted User
content: why is switching to proof of stake being made so complex by insisting on merging the two chains?

author: Deleted User
content: why not simply enable EVM etc. on the beacon chain, and have it take off, and then let the PoW chain run its course separately. Its already 1000gb to sync with geth anyway. why have that carry over when it can just run by itself as PoW and slowly switch to PoS as people feel like it.

author: Deleted User
content: if PoS chain enables EVM

author: sky.cactus
content: There is only one Ethereum blockchain, Proof of Stake just swaps out the consensus mechanism.

author: Deleted User
content: This begs the question what an Ethereum blockchain is

author: Deleted User
content: A clear definition would be awesome
